Eileen Gu deserves another medal for this alone 

#BraveNotPerfect

Moms, we did it!!!!!!!!

What started as the Marshall Plan for Moms in 2021 has become a pathway to universal child care in the largest school system in America.

For decades, child care was framed as a personal struggle for moms, not as a core economic issue for employers and the state. That ends today. And I am so proud of our Moms First community for changing the conversation.

New York today. The rest of the country tomorrow.

Let‚Äôs do this!!

Hey guys, I turned 50 last week.

If you have been listening to my podcast, you already know that midlife and I have had a complicated relationship. And honestly, for a long time, I was not sure if I wanted to make a big deal out of this birthday. There are headlines every day about how 50 is the new 30. And friends, they annoy me. I do not need to be 30 again. I do not even want to be 30 again. 30 was chaotic. 30 was defined by pressure to achieve and pressure to pretend I had everything under control. So the more I thought about it, the clearer it became that 50 is not a replacement age. It is not a rerun or a second chance at youth. 50 is its own season. And I wanted to greet it as myself, not as some younger version I was supposed to channel. We‚Äôre told to hide our age, that it‚Äôs rude to ask women how old we are. I‚Äôm done hiding my age. I am 50 and damn proud of it!

On top of that, so often us women spend a whole lot of time and money planning our weddings, planning our kids‚Äô birthdays (iykyk), but we don‚Äôt spend it celebrating ourselves. I decided I wanted to put in that same amount of time and energy with friends and family to celebrate my own personal milestone‚Ä¶ with lots and lots of dancing.

So I bit the bullet. I planned a girls trip. I planned a party (with help from my husband Nihal). Everyone there helped get me where I am, and I wanted to celebrate them just as much. I did something that felt brave in its own simple way: I let myself be seen. I bought a stunning gold dress. I had the audacity to want to be celebrated. And here is what I learned: You should ABSOLUTELY make a big deal out of the moments that matter to you. You should let the people who love you surround you with joy even if your instinct is to downplay your needs.

I hope this is a reminder to all of you out there to celebrate your life. So if you are on the fence about celebrating yourself, consider this your gentle nudge. I hope you choose to honor your happiness. I hope you celebrate your milestones. I hope you let your village show up for you. And I hope you trust that you are worth celebrating.

(Photo: Maxwell Brown / @maxwellpicswell)

Hey guys,

We've been secretly working on a film about motherhood in America. And today, we're excited to share our official teaser trailer.

For generations, mothers in the U.S. have been told to work harder, smile wider, and do it all ‚Äî while a system built to fail us keeps going with the status quo.

Motherhood has been devalued and dismissed, yet mothers are still expected to hold up the economy with no structural support to stand on.

This film is an investigation into how we got here ‚Äî and what it will take to build something better.

Oh yeah, and we're also trying to make some history in the process. Our goal is to break the Guinness World Record for the most producers ever listed on a film. We want moms everywhere ‚Äî working moms, stay-at-home moms, single moms, church moms ‚Äî to see themselves in it and to be part of our movement.

To get your named added to the film‚Äôs credits as an Associate Producer and help us break the world record, there's 3 things you can do:

1. Share your story ‚Äî in writing or on video.
2. Donate $25 or more (or gift a credit).
3. Sign up to a host a screening this summer.

Ok, moms. Let's do this!

And of course a special shout-out to our producers Culture House Media and French Tuck Media and our amazing director, Raeshem Nijhon.

In 2026 may we see through any attempt to blame women and pit us against each other, and let‚Äôs focus our energy on the systemic issues that are holding all of us back.

Basically, six companies own all the algorithms that we use. And they've made a decision that outrage sells. That it pays to keep us divided.

We need the next generation of engineers to build products that keep us connected, instead of intentionally dividing us.

(Video: Vermont Women's Fund's 2025 celebration)

This week on my Substack, I dive into one of my all-time favorite myths with economist Corinne Low, author of the new book ‚ÄòHaving It All‚Äô.

Here‚Äôs what she brilliantly broke down for me:

Economists divide the world into two spheres: market production (the work that‚Äôs paid and counted) and home production (the work that isn‚Äôt). Both are essential to society, but only one shows up in GDP.

For most of history, women did the home production and men did the market work. Then came the feminist revolution, and women entered the market. The problem? Men never entered the home.

So now, women do both.

We doubled our market participation without halving our home responsibilities. That‚Äôs what Corinne calls the ‚Äúsqueeze‚Äù ‚Äî the strain we feel when we juggle working both in the market and the home. And it‚Äôs baked into the very economics of how we live and work. Every hour women spend on unpaid labor at home is an hour we can‚Äôt spend competing in the marketplace.

And yet when women try to adjust ‚Äî by going part-time, freelancing, or choosing more flexible jobs ‚Äî those decisions get framed as personal failings instead of natural consequences of the flaws in our structural design.

The idea of ‚Äúhaving it all‚Äù was supposed to be aspirational, but it‚Äôs always been an accounting error.

To ‚Äúhave it all,‚Äù you‚Äôd need to live in an economy that values both forms of production ‚Äî home and market ‚Äî equally. You‚Äôd need workplaces that recognize care as infrastructure, not interference. You‚Äôd need partners who share the load.

Instead, we live in a system that still assumes someone else (and most often, a woman) is doing the invisible labor. And when she‚Äôs not, it all falls apart.

And that‚Äôs just the tip of it! Head over to my Substack for more on Corinne‚Äôs research, and stay tuned to our full chat on the 10.29 episode of My So-Called Midlife.

Please join moms across the U.S. on Monday night to discuss what the hell is going on and what we‚Äôre going to do about it.

More speakers to be announced.

Join us here: https://lnkd.in/e9QCJZax

This should be a wakeup call.

The federal government is now targeting women‚Äôs networking events as part of their ‚Äúwar on DEI.‚Äù

It‚Äôs because they‚Äôre afraid.

They‚Äôre afraid of what happens when a group of women get together in the same room. We plot. We talk about how can build a better future for all of us. How we can work together to win child care, to win paid family leave, to build a country in which all of us can thrive.

And they‚Äôre scared of us.

Let‚Äôs be crystal clear: Reversing women‚Äôs progress in the workforce ‚Äî by dismantling DEI, or otherwise ‚Äî will do absolutely nothing to help the vast majority of men.

Men today are being sold a con: that progress is zero-sum. That when women rise, men have to fall. That when people of color get a shot, white people lose theirs. And that‚Äôs just not true.

Progress is not zero sum. üëè

Imposter syndrome is a lie. And for all the history nerds out there, here's one of my favorite history lessons to break it all down!

Recently, during my conversation at Harvey Mudd College to discuss the crisis of disconnection, someone in the audience asked me for advice on how women can overcome imposter syndrome.

If you've been following me for a while, you might know that that's a question people ask me all the time. And in fact, I gave a whole graduation speech about it at Smith College! The thing is, it's sort of a trick question. Because to me, the best way to overcome "imposter syndrome" is to recognize that it's all a lie in the first place! It doesn't mean that your feelings aren't valid. But it does require seeing it for the myth that it is. Imposter syndrome, like bicycle face before it, is another tactic to dissuade women from making progress.

The next time someone with power tries to make you feel like you didn't earn your seat at the table, remember that that's all a strategy.

Why is the school day 8:30 to 3 and the work day 9 to 5?

But go on, keep blaming women for ruining the workplace. üôÉ
.

Once again, stop trying to blame feminism and women for our broken systems. Women didn‚Äôt ‚Äúruin‚Äù the workplace. It‚Äôs ALWAYS been broken.

So, 2025 was a doozy. I felt like I spent so much of this year in battle. To push people and organizations to do the right thing. To give voice to issues that affect women, girls and families. With my inner critic to stop being so hard on myself. And if I'm being honest, all of this outer and inner conflict has left me exhausted. I feel like I am crawling into 2026. I always say that bravery doesn‚Äôt feel good. It‚Äôs actually lonely and isolating. The same is true for deep introspection. And I felt that deeply this year. So this holiday, I am so grateful we staycationed. I've slept. I've meditated. I've prayed. I've played chess with Sai. Crosswords with Shaan. Rotted on the couch with Nihal. And cuddled with Steve. And while I am not fully recovered to do it all again in 2026, because let‚Äôs be honest, we got a lot more battling to do... I've gotten some perspective back that I lost. That the universe does bend towards justice if we make it. That rest is key. That a five-year-old continually beating you in chess is the most humbling thing (and the best healing) you can ask for. Thank you 2025 for all the teachings.

No, women didn‚Äôt ‚Äúruin‚Äù the workplace. We just finally asked it to work for all of us.

On my Substack today, I did a deep dive into *that* New York Times interview.

As always, let me know what you think! I'll share the link in my comments if you're up for reading it. üòâ

It's true: nearly all the job losses in last month's jobs report were women.

And it shouldn't take a PhD in economics to figure out some of the reasons why.

The cost of child care is too damn high!

It's not that women are suddenly deciding to quit their jobs. They're being forced out!

Because when child care costs more than your mortgage, someone is forced to step back. And in America, that "someone" is still almost always the mom...

That's why we need the public AND the private sector to treat child care like the economic imperative that it is.

My organization, Moms First, is working to fix this. And we'd love for you to join us!

Thank you to Holly Corbett for including me in this important story in Forbes. I'll share the full link in my comments.

Happy #FailureFriday!

Last weekend, my team at¬†Moms First¬†and I were so excited for our segment on¬†CBS Sunday Morning¬†(about child care) to air live after months of working behind the scenes on it.

I woke up early, made pancakes, and called the family in to watch. It felt like such a big moment‚Ä¶. one of those rare chances to actually¬†see¬†the movement we‚Äôve been building together. And, I definitely had expectations in my head of exactly how the scene would play out at home for the big reveal.

Then, reality laughed at the plans I had made.

My youngest, Sai, wanted to watch¬†Peppa Pig.¬†Shaan, my oldest, playfully grabbed the remote in a game of keep-away. I got mad. They got madder. Suddenly we were in a big argument in separate corners of the room negotiating screen time instead of watching my big moment unfold. And in the cartoonish tornado of flying words and objects (somehow tiny socks were launched in the air?), the segment had come and gone.

After we all had cooled down in our respective corners of the house, Shaan and Sai came downstairs and, in the most sweet and genuine voices said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, momma.‚Äù I took a breath, laughed, and we sat down to rewatch it together (Thank God for YouTube TV!). Calmly, this time. And, cuddled up on the couch.

The moment I‚Äôd imagined all morning ‚Äî the perfect live debut, the family gathered around in awe ‚Äî didn‚Äôt happen. I got a small circus instead.

And truthfully, I‚Äôm still figuring out how to hold both things at once: the pride and the frustration, the joy and the chaos. How to let the big moments be messy and still mean something.

I know I'm not the only one. Sound like anyone else's Sunday at home?

That‚Äôs a con we‚Äôve been telling women and girls, and it‚Äôs the exact one we‚Äôve set out to expose in our new documentary film about American motherhood, coming soon in 2026.

This film is for every mother doing everything right and still feeling like she‚Äôs failing, not because she is, but because the system is failing her.

Friends,

This was a hard year.

A year of war and fear, of democratic backsliding and institutional silence. A year when too many powerful people chose comfort over courage and neutrality over humanity. I watched institutions I believed in hedge, delay, and look away. I saw how quickly values can collapse when they become inconvenient.

And what kept me going was watching women act anyway, the odds and the outcomes be damned.

Again and again this year, women stepped forward when it cost them something. Their jobs. Their safety. Their privacy. Their reputations. They did not wait for permission or consensus. They did not ask whether the moment was good for their brand. They saw harm, or opportunity to do good, and they refused to be quiet.

Some of this bravery happened on the biggest stages in the world. Some of it happened in courtrooms, classrooms, daycare centers, studios, and hospital rooms. Some of it came from women whose names you know. Some came from women who will never be protected by power or praised by the press.

That is the kind of bravery I want to honor this year. Not perfection. Not heroics. Bravery that looks like staying human inside systems that reward cruelty. Bravery that looks like telling the truth when silence would be safer. Bravery that shows up in care work, in creativity, in science, in justice, and in motherhood.

This list is not exhaustive and it is not ranked. It is just a tiny offering of gratitude despite the immutable noise that constantly asks us, in surround sound, to dismiss and vilify each other.

So thank you to the women who reminded me, in a year that tested so much, that bravery still exists. And yes, it matters.

‚ù§Ô∏è,
Reshma

Asked about Mayor-elect Mamdani, Erika Kirk‚Äôs response to the New York Times was that young women moving to cities like New York shouldn‚Äôt look to the government as a substitute for marriage or kids.

‚ÄúWhat I don‚Äôt want to have happen is women, young women in the city, look to the government as a solution to put off having a family or a marriage, because you‚Äôre relying on the government to support you instead of being united with a husband‚Ä¶‚Äù

I often talk about the cons we tell women and moms, and I want to call one out here.

The birth rate is declining not because the government is being TOO generous to moms and families. No young woman moving to a city like New York thinks the government is her boyfriend and thus she doesn‚Äôt need a real-life partner.

The reality is that women are getting priced out of marriage and parenthood. Marriage for women often means more work, less pay, and zero support. As I‚Äôve said many times, women aren‚Äôt rejecting marriage or motherhood because they don‚Äôt value family ‚Äî they‚Äôre doing the math. And until we fix the equation with paid leave, affordable child care, and real support, we need to stop with the distractions.

Guys, this is HUGE. Our movement for affordable child care was on one of the biggest news shows in the country this morning!

Child care is one of the most important political issues of our time, and the media is taking notice.

Moms, YOU DID THIS. Take a moment to celebrate this small victory and all the other recent wins. This year alone, we‚Äôve had big child care wins in New Mexico and Vermont. Next, we‚Äôre taking the movement to New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Virginia, and Colorado.

So stay loud. Stay focused. And keep sharing your child care stories.

Moms First¬†has something big coming. Trust me on that. üòâ 

Lastly, thank you to¬†CBS Sunday Morning¬†and¬†TRACY SMITH¬†for shining a national spotlight on this crisis and the moms who are working hard to fix it!!!

‚ÄúWhen will you run for office, Reshma?‚Äù

I get asked that a lot, which is so flattering. But the thing is I actually *did* run for office in my 30s. Twice. And I lost pretty epically. Twice!

But since then, I‚Äôve gone on to found¬†Girls Who Code¬†and then¬†Moms First, and now I‚Äôm 50 and we‚Äôre making a film about our work changing the story of American motherhood.

Not only that, we‚Äôre determined to break the Guinness World Record for most associate producers credited in a film. Because this film and this movement is for all of us.

Who‚Äôs ready to join us? Let's do this together!

If you‚Äôre like me, you‚Äôre probably wondering why there‚Äôs been deafening silence from corporate and tech leaders and businesses.

I for one am not happy about it.

To be clear, speaking out against ICE is absolutely the moral thing to do. Period.

But for anyone who isn‚Äôt willing to speak up just because it‚Äôs the right thing to do, let me try to persuade you with a capitalist reason.

These are not normal times. People are scared, they‚Äôre distracted, workers are afraid to show up to work or outright disappearing. It‚Äôs no wonder productivity is dropping and our local economies are taking a hit.

In short: Carrying on like it‚Äôs business as usual isn‚Äôt just morally wrong. It‚Äôs fiscal malpractice.

If you‚Äôre a CEO wondering whether to speak up or not, remember this: Silence isn‚Äôt neutral. It‚Äôs expensive.

If you‚Äôre not going to do it because it‚Äôs the right thing to do, at least do what‚Äôs right for business.

And for any CEOs who wants to talk, please reach out.

Thank you to Fast Company‚Äôs Stephanie Mehta for writing about the business/tech community‚Äôs silence and for speaking with me about it: https://lnkd.in/edry8TDc

I am the proud daughter of refugees from Uganda.

"Before Mamdani‚Äôs political rise, in 2009, attorney and founder of¬†Girls Who Code¬†and Founder of¬†Moms First, Reshma Saujani, 50, laid the groundwork as the first woman of South Asian descent to run for Congress. In 2013, she ran for Public Advocate, becoming the first Indian Ugandan to run for city-wide office. Although she lost both elections, Saujani says her campaigns contributed to the¬†political awakening of the South Asian community¬†that helped elect Mamdani. 

'I would walk into someone‚Äôs apartment in Jackson Heights, and there‚Äôd be a little girl with my poster on her bedroom, and she‚Äôs like, ‚ÄòOh my god, like, I can run now too,‚Äô' said Saujani in an interview with Documented. 'But when I lost, especially [‚Ä¶] in 2013 for public advocate, it was pretty hard, and I remember thinking, a South Asian can never win. And so watching Zorhan run in this race, apply the lessons we learned,¬†and¬†win was just beyond joyful. It was a moment of growth, a kind of personal pride.'

For Saujani, who was born in Chicago but had grown up hearing stories from her father about being forced out of Uganda, the country where he was born. Those stories shaped her desire to be politically engaged.

'[I saw] how you can be a citizen of a country, born and raised for two generations, and [‚Ä¶] be stripped away of your rights in a second,' she said. 'That‚Äôs part of why I‚Äôm an activist, why I‚Äôm an organizer, why I‚Äôm spending my life helping people who don‚Äôt have a voice. [It‚Äôs] because of my parents‚Äô story.'‚Äù

Last month had more layoffs than any October since 2003, with U.S. employers cutting more than 153,000 jobs. Some big companies are attributing it to people being replaced with AI, hence the name "AI layoffs."

I'm calling bullsh*t. Here's why.

Child care in the U.S. is an utter market failure.

And it‚Äôs a failure on the part of our government.

The United States is the wealthiest country in the world that invests the LEAST into child care. We are the only wealthy nation in the world that doesn‚Äôt have guaranteed paid family leave.

It doesn‚Äôt need to be this way. We can do so much better.

(Source of the stat:¬†LendingTree, using the federal definition of ‚Äúaffordable,‚Äù defined as spending no more than 7% of a household income)

Ok all, let's dive into the so-called "ambition gap" between men and women at work.

A new report from Lean In and McKinsey & Company shows that for the first time in the report's 10-year history, significantly fewer women than men want a promotion at work.

Compared with 80% of men in entry-level career stages, 86% in mid-career, and 92% of senior execs, only 69% of women in entry-level stages, 82% mid-career, and 84% of women senior execs reported a desire to advance in their careers.

This is what's been called the "ambition gap."

Here's the thing: it's not exactly a mystery. This is the logical outcome of the past year of companies backsliding on their commitments to women in the workplace.

Women aren't losing ambition. We're just paying attention.

But it doesn't have to be this way.

Moms First is here and on the case. Join us!

The midlife penalty x SNL ‚¨áÔ∏è 

Let's actually unpack it!

Much like the motherhood penalty, the midlife penalty is an actual cost women bear as we get older ‚Äî because as women age,¬†the wage gap widens.

In fact, women ages 45-64 experience a whopping $16,490 earnings gap compared with white men ‚Äî roughly¬†four times¬†that of women ages 15-24. 

That‚Äôs not surprising when you consider how women are systematically disadvantaged in the workplace. We‚Äôre too young until we‚Äôre too old ‚Äî not taken seriously in the early stages of our careers, not¬†supported¬†with child care or paid leave if we become mothers, and then, once we think we‚Äôre finally through the woods, we‚Äôre ‚Äúpast our prime.‚Äù Meanwhile, the demands at home can feel unrelenting. Millions are caring for both parents and kids as part of the ‚Äúsandwich generation,‚Äù labor that can go woefully unrecognized. It‚Äôs no wonder older women are grossly¬†underrepresented¬†in senior leadership.

And it‚Äôs hard to show up fully both at work and¬†at home when your hormones are running wild. Our health continues to be¬†understudied, with¬†less than 5%¬†of global research and development funding going towards women, and¬†less than 1%¬†of NIH funding going towards menopause. As a result, we still don‚Äôt fully understand how gender and menopause influence other age-related health issues, like¬†heart attacks and Alzheimer‚Äôs disease ‚Äî leaving older women to suffer from them disproportionately. Unsurprisingly, these¬†care disparities¬†and¬†health risks¬†are only exacerbated for women of color.

So what can we do about it? For starters, we need to create real support systems for women as we get older. At a minimum, companies should be regularly promoting and retaining women in leadership roles at the same rate as men. They could also consider offering¬†menopause and caregiving benefits¬†to help women in midlife stay in the workforce ‚Äî and help recuperate the¬†$1.8 million¬†per year menopause costs in lost working hours.

Outside of corporate America, we need greater¬†funding¬†for long-neglected research into menopause and other women‚Äôs health issues, so that we can treat the literal, physical symptoms that are holding us back. And ‚Äî maybe most important of all ‚Äî we need a broader shift in our culture. We need to fundamentally change the way we see middle-aged and above women in our lives, to¬†listen to them, and to hold their stories closely and with care.

People always talk about women‚Äôs lives as governed by the dreaded ‚Äúbiological clock.‚Äù Implicit in that is a myth that once we hit midlife, our time is up ‚Äî that there‚Äôs nothing left to live for. But it‚Äôs an illusion ‚Äî a vanishing act of epically sexist and ageist proportions. As difficult as midlife can be, it also comes with great joys and freedoms: wisdom, confidence, peace with our lot in life. If, one day, women can enjoy a midlife¬†without¬†the midlife penalty, we can fully step into the power we‚Äôve always had.
